Hybrid modeling-based temperature and humidity adaptive control for a multi-zone HVAC system Yuliang Jiang Methodology Writing – original draft Shanying Zhu Conceptualization Methodology Supervision Writing – review & editing ⁎ Qimin Xu Software Validation Bo Yang Writing – review & editing Project administration Xinping Guan Supervision Writing – review & editing Department of Automation, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, China Department of Automation, Shanghai Jiao Tong University Shanghai 200240 China Department of Automation, Shanghai Jiao Tong University,Shanghai, 200240,China Key Laboratory of System Control and Information Processing, Ministry of Education of China, Shanghai 200240, China Key Laboratory of System Control and Information Processing, Ministry of Education of China Shanghai 200240 China Key Laboratory of System Control and Information Processing, Ministry of Education of China, Shanghai,200240,China Shanghai Engineering Research Center of Intelligent Control and Management, Shanghai 200240, China Shanghai Engineering Research Center of Intelligent Control and Management Shanghai 200240 China Shanghai Engineering Research Center of Intelligent Control and Management, Shanghai, 200240,China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Automation, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, China. Department of Automation, Shanghai Jiao Tong University Shanghai 200240 China In this paper, we study multi-zone air environment comfort and building energy conversation for the heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) system. Each zone is equipped with the air-handling unit (AHU) and fan coil unit to regulate the supply air state for comfortable zone climate. It is known that the multi-zone air environment appears spatial and temporal variation due to the hygro-thermal interaction which is an extremely complex nonlinear dynamic process. In this study, hybrid models incorporating the first-principles model with full form dynamic linearization (FFDL)-based data-driven model have been proposed to precisely describe the multi-zone climate dynamics including unknown nonlinearity and uncertainty. Then model-free adaptive control (MFAC) scheme is designed for multi-zone climate control, which contains controller design, parameter estimation and reset mechanism to ensure system control performance. Finally, different case studies are conducted to test the performance of model prediction and system control for the multi-zone climate environment. Model validation shows that the zone climate prediction of the proposed hybrid model shows better agreement with actual measured data. The step response results display that the hybrid model-based MFAC can realize multi-zone climate control performance improvement in faster convergence without stable bias. By comparing with prior work, the hybrid model-based MFAC has the potential to get closer to actual situation in cost-effective multi-zone climate control. Keywords Multi-zone HVAC system Hygro-thermal interaction Hybrid modeling Full form dynamic linearization Adaptive control Data availability Data is available online. 1 Introduction Building energy conservation has become one of highlighting social issues due to building energy consumption accounting for a large proportion of total energy consumption [1]. Heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) systems in large multi-zone buildings like airports, which are responsible for the zone climate and indoor air quality (IAQ) regulation [2], is the main contributor of building energy consumption [3]. Different from single zone climate control, the multi-zone climate control can be regarded as adjusting the specified small zone temperature and humidity in a bigger one, where the small zones are open to each other. The inter-zone interaction including thermal interaction, moisture interaction and coupled hygro-thermal interaction is not completely negligible. The adjacent zone climate affects the objective zone climate increasing uncertainty of multi-zone climate dynamics and difficulty of multi-zone climate control. The goals of improving occupancy comfort and reducing energy consumption motivate a variety of research for highly-effective multi-zone HVAC system operating and controlling schemes. Indoor temperature and humidity considered as especially important measures of thermal comfort along with other factors like indoor air velocity, metabolic rate, etc., collectively affect occupancy comfort and occupant health [4]. Humidity regulation is usually ignored in building climate control, which makes occupancy comfort compromised and leads to poor humidity control [5]. For the purpose of energy-efficient building climate control, a wide variety of advanced control methods [6,7] have been investigated. Model predictive control (MPC) [8] has been one of the most widely applied control techniques for HVAC system. Applications of MPC in building climate control can be classified into two categories: the trajectory tracking MPC and the economic MPC. The trajectory tracking MPC aims to drive relevant temperature or humidity to the given set point by minimizing the tracking errors and control efforts [9–11]. In [10,11], Mei proposed an autonomous hierarchical control method consisting of two layers for direct expansion air conditioning systems. The upper layer was designed to use an open loop controller to achieve tradeoff steady states (indoor air temperature, moisture content and CO 2 concentration) by minimizing the system energy consumption. MPC controller was employed in the lower layer to track steady states at the required level. The optimization function of the economic MPC for building climate control involves total energy usage. In [12], Huang took into account both thermal comfort and energy cost into the optimization objective of MPC strategy. The results showed that the proposed MPC strategy saved a large amount energy without sacrificing much thermal comfort. Other problem formulation of MPC can refer to informative review papers [6,13,14]. The advantages of MPC for building climate control are that it can tradeoff conflicting indices such as maintaining thermal comfort while decreasing energy consumption, dealing with multiple-input and multiple-output (MIMO) problems and using numerical optimization. However, an accurate prediction model for building HVAC system is the indispensable prerequisite. In despite of various models proposed [15–18], unmodeled dynamics and unknown uncertainties still exist which adversely affect system control performance and energy efficiency. Data-driven control methods, free of accurate first-principles model and only relying on running data, provide a different solution to building climate control problem. The existing data-driven techniques such as iterative feedback tuning (IFT) [19], virtual reference feedback tuning (VRFT) [20], iterative learning control (ILC) [21,22], model free adaptive control (MFAC) [23,24], etc., have been discussed for controller design and analysis. In [25], Chi reformulated the HVAC system into a virtual linear incremental form by iterative dynamic linearization method for controller design only with I/O data information. The proposed distributed iterative learning temperature control (DILTC) method is suitable for repeatable disturbances. More recently, learning-based techniques such as reinforcement learning [26,27] and deep reinforcement learning (DRL) [28,29] have been applied to building climate control without any modeling knowledge. In [30], an energy optimization problem with the consideration of temperature regulation and stochastic zone occupancy for a multi-zone commercial building was reformulated as a Markov game. The proposed multi-agent DRL-based control method can minimize energy cost without requirement of any prior knowledge of system parameters and can be implemented in the absence of zone thermal dynamics. In [31], Du compared the deep deterministic policy gradient (DDPG) strategy and the deep Q network (DQN) in energy consumption and thermal comfort for the multi-zone residential HVAC climate control. Model-free deep reinforcement learning can exploit the interaction information between objective zone and ambient environment and without prior knowledge of zone thermal dynamics. This approach just achieves thermal comfort and indoor air quality within accepted range rather than a fixed set point. Moreover, DRL may cause unstable or large deviation when action-value function is represented by a nonlinear estimator [29]. The multi-zone building climate control is mainly attributed to regulation of both temperature and humidity, while humidity regulation is rarely considered in the researches mentioned above. Inappropriate humidity (too dry in winter or too wet in summer) can adversely affect occupancy comfort and occupant health for a long time. There are several issues to be addressed when incorporating humidity into multi-zone building climate control. Difficult modeling for multi-zone buildings has become one of challenging characteristics [32] in building climate control, especially considering humidity. It is worth noting that multi-zone building HVAC system is a slow heat and moisture transfer dynamic process with strong nonlinearity and thermodynamic inertia. A variety of modeling techniques [33,34] have been investigated and improved to obtain precise thermodynamic model as much as possible. In [35], a meta-zone aggregating multiple zones in real building was proposed to reduce the reliance on a high-resolution zone climate model of MPC. The strong nonlinear behavior is inevitable during the heat and moisture exchange between outdoor environment, ambient zones, and cannot be modeled appropriately [36]. Other uncertain or influential factors like random occupancy, outside weather and so on also impede precise mechanism modeling. Austin [37] built a thermal disturbance model induced by random occupancy and used the Kalman filter to estimate the unmodeled disturbance. Guo [38] suggested the aggregation idea to deal with the problem of simultaneously identifying an aggregate thermal dynamic model and unknown disturbances from input–output data of multi-zone buildings. The thermal dynamics and related disturbance was considered to improve the accuracy of the building temperature model. The effects of unmodeled disturbances of coupling heat and moisture and hygro-thermal dynamics within and between zones have not been considered in these work. For a multi-zone building, the air environment of several zones is time-varying and interactional. The heat and moisture transfer process among zones becomes more complicated and harder to obtain satisfactory occupancy comfort control. Raman [35] summarized and compared with literature on multi-zone model predictive control which could be roughly categorized into zone-level commands only, AHU-level commands only and both AHU-level and zone-level commands. In that work, zone-level input was obtained by optimizing the energy consumption problem subject to constraints of zone thermal comfort with the consideration of both sensible and latent heat. The zone-level commands as the set points guided the AHU-level control. Motivated by the above analysis, effective zone-level control schemes for multi-zone HVAC system to achieve occupancy comfort improvement with consideration of unknown disturbances should be proposed. In this work, we study zone-level commands and present a hybrid modeling-based adaptive control method taking into account coupling heat and moisture effect, influence of multi-zone hygro-thermal interaction and unmodeled hygro-thermal dynamics (such as random occupancy, electronic devices use, occupant breath, etc.). The hybrid model for multi-zone building HVAC system consisting of the first-principles model and data-driven model is the key premise of effective controller design. In a summary, the main contributions of this work can be addressed as follows: • The first principles-based temperature and humidity models are developed which consider the coupling effect of heat and moisture, the known thermal interaction such as convection of neighboring zones. Unmodeled zone climate dynamics and unknown uncertainties are formulated as concise incremental data models by dynamic linearlization method. • A full-form dynamic linearization (FFDL) model-based MFAC scheme is proposed by solving a designed optimization problem to make control decisions for multi-zone building climate control. For convenience of the MFAC scheme, the first-principles model is conducted an equivalent reformulation by dynamic linearization method. Then the first-principles model and data-based residual model as hybrid models are integrated in a parallel fashion and controlled by same inputs in the proposed MFAC scheme. • The proposed MFAC scheme contains parameter estimation algorithm, controller design and reset mechanism to provide satisfactory control performance. Parameter estimation algorithm is necessary for exact values of the time-varying parameters which are hard to obtain for the proposed controller and hybrid model. The performance indices of air state tracking and model prediction are involved into the controller design for higher model accuracy and better comfort control performance. The reset mechanism is introduced to enhance the ability of time-varying parameter estimation. The remainder of this work is organized as follows: Section 2 gives the system description and develops models for multi-zone hygro-thermal dynamics. Section 3 presents the MFAC scheme for multi-zone climate control. Section 4 demonstrates the simulation results of model validation and control performance. Section 5 draws conclusions of this work. 2 System description and modeling The indoor air environment comfort and energy saving in large-scale multi-zone buildings is mainly attributed to the reasonable operation of HVAC system. In this section, the comprehensive hygro-thermal models are developed based upon the understanding of multi-zone HVAC climate dynamics. 2.1 HVAC system description for the multi-zone building The goal of the multi-zone building HVAC system is to provide suitable supply air to every zone with minimal building energy consumption to achieve occupancy comfort. Fig. 1 displays the common schematic of a multi-zone building HVAC system. Outside fresh air is first filtered through the filter and then blown through the cooling coil by the centrifugal fan to regulate the temperature close to the indoor air temperature. The pretreatment process is accomplished by selecting the appropriate ventilation strategy conducted by the make-up air-handling unit (MAU) [39]. Subsequently, the pretreated fresh air with indoor return air is mixed as original supply air. For hot-humid climate and the cooling mode is turned on, the original supply air is usually warm and humid and needs to be cooled and dehumidified. Then the mixed air is implemented secondary processing by the air-handling unit (AHU). The cooling coil reduces the mixed air temperature and humidity to be ready supply air temperature ( T c a ) and relative humidity ( W c a ) by tuning the flow of cold water. For cold-humid climate, it is difficult to achieve dehumidification process at the heating mode unless the dehumidification mode is turned on with cooling state. And the heating mode is turned on for temperature regulation. When the humidity of the ready supply air is regulated to meet the supply air scheme, the supply air can adjust the zone relative humidity to the comfortable value. But the supply air temperature is still low. Thus, it is reheated by the reheat coils of the fan coil unit up to supply air temperature where the reheat coils regulate temperature of ready supply air but not change supply air humidity, i.e., T s a i > T c a , W s a i = W c a ( T s a i and W s a i are the supplied air temperature and humidity of the zone i , respectively). The end of the fan coil is complicated and extra control for supply air volume needs to be designed. In this study, the multi-zone climate is mainly regulated by changing supply air temperature and humidity. The supply air volume flow rate to individual zone is determined in advance according to the pre-set value and remains basically unchanged for a period of time, which can be achieved with the aid of dampers. And there are several candidate air volume values which can be chosen for the supply air volume requirement. When the temperature and humidity requirements for supply air are met, the final supply air will be supplied to the conditioned zones. 2.2 Multi-zone building hygro-thermal dynamics modeling Considering the indoor climate for a certain zone of the multi-zone building, the supply air is the main contributor for the zone heat and humidity comfort regulation. Besides that, there are other factors which have exerted non-negligible influence on zone climate control. The air temperature and humidity of an open zone can be affected by nearby zones due to air convection. The surrounding surfaces inside the zone like walls, ceilings, floors and other mutual surfaces make an impact on hygro-thermal comfort through the way of conduction. Some other considerations like occupants activity [40], lights and electronic equipment, personal humidifier, outside weather, etc., should also be involved in zone climate dynamics [41]. In addition, spatially inhomogeneous distribution of supply air to the zone is easy to be neglected and that also deserves to be concerned in a large-scale zone. Based upon above analysis, temperature and humidity dynamics of an objective zone should be considered together for comprehensive zone climate dynamics of a multi-zone building. Here, let the number of zones in the multi-zone buildings be n . Thermal dynamics for a conditioned zone i ( i = 1 , 2 , … , n ) has been formulated as follows [41]: (1) d T i d t = m s a i C a ( T s a i − T i ) C i + ∑ j ∈ S i K j A j ( T S i j − T i ) C i + ∑ p ∈ N i m p C a ( T p − T i ) C i + K o i ( T o − T i ) C i + q i C i + f T i ( T s a i , W s a i , T m , W m , T f p i , W f p i ) , (2) d T S i j d t = K j A j C j ( T i − T S i j ) + K j A j C j ( T o − T S i j ) , (3) d T S i j d t = K j A j C j ( T i − T S i j ) + K j A j C j ( T p − T S i j ) , where Eq. (1) represents the dynamic change of zone temperature T i with consideration of the influencing factors mentioned earlier. Eqs. (2) and (3) are used to calculate the temperature of surrounding surface T S i j which can be affected by outside temperature or neighboring zone temperature. T s a i and W s a i denote supply air temperature and humidity, respectively, which are controlled by AHU; T m and W m represent measured air state of zone m , which also include the measured values of the objective zone i and the neighboring zone p ; And N i is the neighboring zone set of the objective zone; T o denotes outside temperature and its heat transfer coefficient is K o i ; q i is used to describe heat gain and loss generated from other thermal factors like lighting and occupant activity, etc; T f p i and W f p i are the temperature and humidity prediction output which can be clearly modeled based on prior knowledge; C i denotes the overall thermal capacity of the objective zone; C j is the overall thermal capacity of the j th surface surrounding zone i; C a denotes the specific heat of air; m s a i and m p are mass flow of supplied air and neighboring zone air, respectively; K j is the overall heat transfer coefficient of the surface j in surrounding surface set S i ; A j is corresponding surface contact area. Different from [41], the last item f T i ( ⋅ ) is added to depict the unmodeled dynamics and unknown uncertainty which cannot be explicitly formulated with known prior knowledge. The coupling thermal and wet effect should be considered into the comprehensive zone climate dynamics. Similarly, the humidity dynamics [34] for a conditioned zone i is as follows: (4) d W i d t = R g T i V i P i d a m s a i ( W s a i − W i ) 1 + W s a i + ∑ p ∈ N i m p ( W p − W i ) 1 + W p + R g T i V i P i d a h i + f W i ( T s a i , W s a i , T m , W m , T f p i , W f p i ) , where Eq. (4) represents dynamic change of zone humidity W i . Other factors affecting indoor humidity like occupant breath, indoor plants, personal humidifiers are considered into moisture gain and loss h i ; R g is the specific gas constant of dry air at the partial pressure P i d a ; V i is equal to the volume of the zone. There are many interacting elements that affect the indoor relative humidity — starting from various sources and different materials in building that absorb and release the humidity. It actually reflects the dynamic variation of the latent thermal load which also needs to be controlled for occupant comfort. It is not trivial to obtain a clear formulation for dynamic variation of the latent thermal load. In this paper, we model all these effects from interacting elements as uncertainty and unknown nonlinearity. Different from [34], the last item f W i ( ⋅ ) is used to depict unknown and uncertain humidity dynamics which cannot be depicted by the known prior knowledge. Overall nomenclature of (1)–(4) are listed in Table 1. 2.3 Control of the multi-zone HVAC system For a multi-zone building, the models of temperature and humidity of each zone are modeled by considering the coupled hygro-thermal effects within and between zones. The temperature and humidity sensors are used to measure the zone temperature and humidity. Each AHU is mounted three sensors at the locations of supply air, return air and zone to measure the temperature and humidity. Assuming that supply air has evenly distributed in each controlled zone for a large full-scale building with multiple zones. And the location and number of temperature and humidity sensors are set reasonably for effective hygro-thermal information. This will guide the zone-level controller to obtain good supply air scheme. The obtained supply air temperature and humidity of each zone is the set point command of the AHU-level control. Taking cooling mode as an example, the heating mode of the system is similar. By comparing the measured values with the desired zone temperature and humidity (zone-level control goal) and tuning the corresponding electronic valves such as flow valves of hot and cold water, the supply air temperature and humidity will reach the supply air requirement (AHU-level control goal) by PI control approach. Then an electrical signal is emitted to the air volume control and suitable air volume is chosen before the supply air being sent to the zone. According the experience of the whole load, several candidate air volume values can be set to avoid the dead-bands of the supply air. For this complicated multi-zone hygro-thermal system, it is hard to design suitable controller directly based on above the first-principles models. Motivated by above analysis and with the consideration of many operational data, this paper pursues to design effective multi-zone supply air scheme based on accurate hygro-thermal models for the control objective of higher occupancy comfort in spite of unknown disturbances. 3 MFAC scheme for the multi-zone HVAC system For a multi-zone HVAC system, the indoor temperature and humidity is time-varying due to room load and occupant demand. In practical operation of the HVAC system, a simple but robust controller with less time-consuming is more required. To this end, an effective control scheme for multi-zone building climate regulation is proposed in this section. 3.1 Discrete-time models for zone hygro-thermal dynamics The discretization of the above temperature and humidity models is conducted first due to controller design for digital implementation at proper sampling time t s . According to the actual measured data y m i ( k ) = [ T m i ( k ) , W m i ( k ) ] T and the data y f p i ( k ) = [ T f p i ( k ) , W f p i ( k ) ] T of the first-principles model, the model mismatch deviations can be obtained. These bias data y d i ( k ) = [ T d i ( k ) , W d i ( k ) ] T is used to predict system unmodeled dynamics with u i ( k ) = [ T s a i ( k ) , W s a i ( k ) ] T as the input. This can be viewed as a nonlinear system with unknown input and output orders n y m i and n u i . And n y m i is chosen as the same as n y i for obtain the unknown nonlinear and uncertain data. Without lost generality, the implicit formulations in Eqs. (7) and (8) can be represented by a general unknown MIMO nonlinear function F d i ( ⋅ ) . Specifically, the pseudo orders can be suitably selected (such as L y i = 2 , L u i = 2 ) for following dynamic linearization data modeling with lower dimensions and without characteristic information loss of the original system [42]. The control schematic of the hybrid model-based MFAC enabled closed-loop multi-zone HVAC system is shown in Fig. 2. The first-principles model and the data-based FFDL model are integrated in parallel form for zone climate dynamics prediction. The hygro-thermal interaction of neighboring zones has been considered into the comprehensive models, which exerts nontrivial influence on conditioned zone climate control. 3.3.1 Control action calculation Given the reference profile y r i ( k ) = [ T r i ( k ) , W r i ( k ) ] T , the MFAC controller is designed by building an optimization function involved in the control performance of profile tracking, modeling prediction and control effort. The formulation of the optimization objective for zone i is presented as follows: (14) J ( u i ( k ) ) = ‖ y r i ( k + 1 ) − y p r e i ( k + 1 ) ‖ 2 + ‖ y i ( k ) − y p r e i ( k + 1 ) ‖ 2 + λ ‖ Δ u i ( k ) ‖ 2 , where the first item C 1 ≜ y r i ( k + 1 ) − y p r e i ( k + 1 ) represents the tracking error between the predictive output of the proposed model and the reference profile; The second item C 2 ≜ y i ( k ) − y p r e i ( k + 1 ) represents the prediction error between the model predictive output and actual measured data; y i ( k ) = [ T i ( k ) , W i ( k ) ] T denotes the measured air state data of zone i ; The last item C 3 ≜ Δ u i ( k ) imposes a restriction on the change of input at the k th time instant; u i ( k ) = [ T s a i ( k ) , W s a i ( k ) ] T is system input as stated earlier; λ > 0 is a weighting factor. According to (12), (13) and solve (14), the MFAC controller is presented as follows: (15) u i ( k ) = u i ( k − 1 ) − [ y r i ( k + 1 ) + y i ( k ) − 2 y f p i ( k ) − 2 y d i ( k ) ] θ i ( k ) λ + 2 θ i ( k ) 2 − 2 ∑ l = 1 L y i [ ϕ f p i l ( k ) Δ y f p i ( k − l + 1 ) + ϕ d i l ( k ) Δ y d i ( k − l + 1 ) ] θ i ( k ) λ + 2 θ i ( k ) 2 − 2 ∑ l = L y i + 2 L u i + L y i [ ϕ f p i l ( k ) + ϕ d i l ( k ) ] Δ u i ( k + L y i − l + 1 ) θ i ( k ) λ + 2 θ i ( k ) 2 , where θ i ( k ) = ϕ f p i L y i + 1 ( k ) + ϕ d i L y i + 1 ( k ) . See Appendix B for the derivation process. The control action of zone i is calculated online by using I/O information of both the first-principles model and data model. Specifically, the first two items of the proposed controller indicate that the supply air of zone i in the present moment is determined by the system input at the last moment, the first-principles model output and the data model output in the present moment. The historical input and output information of both the first-principles models and data models is involved in the remaining items. The impact of neighboring zones on control action of zone i has been implicitly contained in the proposed comprehensive models ( y f p i ( k ) and y d i ( k ) ) and historical increments ( Δ y f p i ( k − l + 1 ) and Δ y d i ( k − l + 1 ) ). The proposed controller can properly adapt the fusion of both the first-principles model and data residual model, which can well achieve multi-zone building climate control with the consideration of unmodeled nonlinearity and unknown uncertainty. These historical output ( y f p i ( k − l + 1 ) , y d i ( k − l + 1 ) , l = 1 , … , L y i ) and input ( u i ( k − 1 ) , u i ( k − l + 1 ) , l = L y i + 2 , … , L y i + L u i ) can be known in advance during the running of the HVAC system. However, there exist extremely critical time-varying parameters Φ f p i ( k ) and Φ d i ( k ) undetermined which can reflect and adapt zone hygro-thermal variation caused by neighboring zones and other factors mentioned in previous section. The possible complexities of hygro-thermal dynamics in multi-zone buildings, such as nonlinearity, time-varying parameters, or time-varying structures, are involved in the time-varying parameter matrices Φ f p i ( k ) and Φ f p i ( k ) . Therefore, exact PPJM estimation algorithm should be designed. 3.3.2 PPJM estimation The PPJM Φ f p i ( k ) and Φ f p i ( k ) for model prediction and control implementation can be estimated by choosing suitable estimation criterion with obtained data. To avoid the estimation results being too sensitive to some inaccurate sampled data (due to interference or sensor failure), the recursive estimation is used which is adaptive and robust to time-varying parameters, time-varying structures, time-varying phases, etc [42]. The estimation criterion functions in this paper for Φ f p i ( k ) and Φ d i ( k ) are presented as follows: (16) J ( Φ f p i ( k ) ) = ‖ Δ y f p i ( k ) − Φ f p i ( k ) Δ H f p i ( k − 1 ) ‖ 2 + μ 1 ‖ Φ f p i ( k ) − Φ ̂ f p i ( k − 1 ) ‖ 2 , (17) J ( Φ d i ( k ) ) = ‖ Δ y d i ( k ) − Φ d i ( k ) Δ H d i ( k − 1 ) ‖ 2 + μ 2 ‖ Φ d i ( k ) − Φ ̂ d i ( k − 1 ) ‖ 2 , where μ 1 > 0 and μ 2 > 0 are weighting parameters; Φ ̂ f p i ( k ) and Φ ̂ d i ( k ) are the estimation of the corresponding to the truth value. Minimize above cost functions with respect to Φ f p i ( k ) and Φ d i ( k ) , then the estimation of PPJM can be obtained. Φ ̂ f p i ( k ) = [ ϕ ̂ f p i 1 ( k ) , … , ϕ ̂ f p i L y i + L u i ( k ) ] T , ϕ ̂ f p i l ( k ) = ϕ ̂ f p i , 11 l ( k ) ϕ ̂ f p i , 12 l ( k ) ϕ ̂ f p i , 21 l ( k ) ϕ ̂ f p i , 22 l ( k ) , l = 1 , 2 , … , L y i + L u i . Substituting the Φ ̂ f p i ( k ) and Φ ̂ d i ( k ) into Eq. (15), we finally obtain the controller u i ( k ) . 3.3.3 Reset mechanism The PPJM estimation is the key to hybrid model prediction and directly affects the control performance. It is not immune to the input and output data. Very small control increment or PPJM with different signs may make the updating ability of the estimate algorithm become worse. Thus necessary restrictions should be set to ensure an effective estimate. In order to enhance the tracking capacity of the proposed estimation algorithm on time-varying parameters, the estimation values need to be checked and meet some conditions according the control requirement. The PPJM can be reasonably assumed to be diagonally dominant and sign invariable [42]. The estimation results will be restarted by the initial value once these conditions are not met. To this end, necessary reset mechanism should be proposed to revive the estimation algorithm. The following reset mechanism for Φ ̂ f p i ( k ) is proposed as follows: (20) if s i g n ϕ ̂ f p i , p p L y i + 1 ( k ) ≠ s i g n ϕ ̂ f p i , p p L y i + 1 ( 1 ) , o r ∣ ϕ ̂ f p i , p p L y i + 1 ( k ) ∣ < b 2 , o r ∣ ϕ ̂ f p i , p p L y i + 1 ( k ) ∣ > ϵ b 2 , then ϕ ̂ f p i , p p L y i + 1 ( k ) = ϕ ̂ f p i , p p L y i + 1 ( 1 ) . if s i g n ϕ ̂ f p i , p q L y i + 1 ( k ) ≠ s i g n ϕ ̂ f p i , p q L y i + 1 ( 1 ) , o r ∣ ϕ ̂ f p i , p q L y i + 1 ( k ) ∣ > b 1 , then ϕ ̂ f p i , p q L y i + 1 ( k ) = ϕ ̂ f p i , p q L y i + 1 ( 1 ) . p ≠ q , p , q = 1 , 2 . ϕ ̂ f p i , p p L y i + 1 ( 1 ) , ϕ ̂ f p i , p q L y i + 1 ( 1 ) are the initial values of corresponding estimation values, respectively. s i g n ( ⋅ ) represents the signum function. b 1 and b 2 are given constants, which meets ϵ ≥ 1 and b 2 > b 1 ( 2 ϵ + 1 ) . The reset mechanism for Φ ̂ d i ( k ) is similar and omitted here. Remark 1 The diagonal dominance condition is the assumption of the input–output relationship. For MIMO systems, this condition may be the only viable option to describe the coupled relationship between the variables of the system since the system model is unknown and only the I/O data of the system up to the current moment is known. The physical significance of sign invariance is that the corresponding controlled system output should not be reduced when the control input increases. This can be considered as a quasilinear property of the system. There are many actual system that meet this assumption such as temperature control system and pressure control system. The MFAC scheme including controller design, parameter estimation and reset mechanism to ensure the multi-zone climate control performance. The proposed controller only uses I/O information of both the first-principles model and data residual model without knowing the structure and parameter of the unmodeled dynamics. Remarkably, the control input is obtained through an online optimization without heavy computation burden. The implementation process of the MFAC scheme has been summarized in Algorithm 1. 4 Simulation results and discussion 4.1 Building description In order to test the model accuracy and control performance of the proposed MFAC scheme, we consider the check-in hall of an airport with four zones as shown in Fig. 3. These zones are separated by walls, windows and automatic doors whose area of these partitions can be known. All of the four zones are isolated from the outside environment by a large glass wall. The investigated zones have significant coupling relationship of the hygro-thermal interaction with neighboring zones and outside environment. Moreover, each zone with respective occupancy schedule generates different climate dynamics. The supply air to each zone provided by HVAC system can be obtained by the above control algorithm. In this study, three case studies have been carried on to investigate model prediction accuracy, control performance and energy consumption of the proposed MFAC scheme. 4.2 Model validation for multi-zone HVAC system The accuracy of the proposed hybrid model is validated in four different test zones. The measured temperature data is from the actual experiment in a check-in hall. The humidity data fails to collect in previous work [16] due to the lack of consideration for the humidity model. In order to verify the effectiveness and accuracy of the proposed humidity model, we assume that the set point for humidity plays the role of the measured humidity. For comparison, the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) and Mean Absolute Error (MAE) are used to evaluate the relevant performance. (21) R M S E = 1 n ∑ i = 1 n ( z i − z ̂ i ) 2 , (22) M A E = 1 n ∑ i = 1 n | z i − z ̂ i | , where z i and z ̃ i denote the actual measured values and predictive values, respectively, corresponding to a set of simulation data. The temperature model and humidity model are applied to the above indicators to evaluate the accuracy, respectively. The model validation results are illustrated in Fig. 4. Both the first-principles model and the proposed hybrid model can capture zone hygro-thermal dynamics. By comparison, the prediction results of the hybrid model are in better agreement with the measured data. The first-principles model may generate obvious prediction bias since unmeasured or unmeasurable disturbances within and between zones are not considered. Tables 2 and 3 show the prediction accuracy of the proposed hybrid model and make a comparison with the first-principles model. Both RMSE and MAE of the hybrid model are less than that of the first-principles model. From the comparison results, the hybrid model is closer to the measured data since the online data information is involved for model parameter estimation and hygro-thermal dynamics prediction. 4.3 Control performance simulation 4.3.1 Step response performance The hygro-thermal step response performance of the proposed MFAC algorithm is examined in the aforementioned testing zones. PI control strategy is employed for performance comparison under the same setting conditions. The first-principles model-based PI control and hybrid model-based PI control have been compared to observe the influence of unmodeled dynamics or uncertainties on step response. Four zones are set to different situations to test step response performance. The initial values have been set as required by the actual condition. The black solid line represents the setting air state of each zone. The case of the zone-1 is to change air temperature while keeps air humidity constant. The case of the zone-2 is the reverse of that in the zone-1, which keeps the air temperature constant while changes the air relative humidity. Zone-3 considers the case that both temperature and humidity are changed with the same trend. Zone-4 takes into account the drop in temperature and humidity. All zone climate dynamics has influence on each other and strives to reach their respective set state. The hygro-thermal step response results of the four zones during simulation time are presented in Fig. 5. It can be observed that the proposed MFAC scheme has faster response time than PI control in driving zone temperature and humidity to respective set state. Although there exist some fluctuations during the dynamic response for MFAC scheme, it shows fast convergence rate and reaches the setpoints faster than PI control. From Fig. 5(a) and (b), it can be found that obvious fluctuations in the humidity response simultaneously occur when the air temperature changes in zone-1. The similar effect also occurs in zone-2 (see Fig. 5(c) and (d)) where the air temperature simultaneously fluctuates more obviously with zone humidity changing. The above phenomena reveals coupling relationship between temperature and humidity. From the response results of all zones and comparing with PI control, the proposed MFAC scheme reaches desired air state with less time and without tracking deviation during the stable period. Although oscillations may be generated during the dynamic response process by MFAC, the fast convergence speed is able to meet the slow dynamic process of the HVAC system. In addition, the dynamic response results of hybrid model-based control show better performance than that of the first-principles model-based control by comparing PI control based on different models. 4.3.2 Energy consumption comparison Different air supply schemes may lead to different energy consumption mainly related to the temperature T s a i and flow rate m s a i of the supply air. In general, when the same zone comfort is achieved by cooling or heating, the heating mode consumes more energy for the reason that the air conditioning is mainly for cooling function, and the heating mode is only its side item. In the view of energy saving and zone comfort, the cooling mode is set preferentially and the modes of both heating and cooling are avoided as much as possible. The cooling mode is set in the four zones. According to the proposed supply air scheme, it is necessary to calculate the energy consumption of each zone generated by AHUs. In this study, we calculate the cooling energy consumption directly affected by the air supply air scheme. The energy consumption of latent load affected by the flow and temperature of the desiccant solution is not considered. To calculate and evaluate the system energy efficiency, the simplified energy consuming models [12] are adopted. (23) Δ T c i = ( 1 − D o p i ) T r e i + D o p i T o − T s a i , (24) P c i = m s a i C a Δ T c i C O P , (25) P f i = f 0 + f 1 m s a i + f 2 m s a i 2 , where Δ T c i is the supply air temperature variation between the inlet and the outlet of the cooling coil; D o p i represents the opening degree of the outdoor air damper; P c i denotes the energy cost of the chiller; Coefficient of performance (COP) is a fixed value which reflects the ratio of energy conversion efficiency of the chiller. T r e i is the return air temperature of zone i ; P f i is the energy consumption of the fan, and the parameters f 0 , f 1 and f 2 are given constants [17]. The total energy consumption is the sum of P c i and P f i for each conditioned zone. Based upon above energy consumption formulations, we have compared the cooling energy consumption of the four zones generated by MFAC and PI control, respectively. Cooling energy consumption generated by different models-based PI control strategy has also been compared in this case. All the external conditions like outdoor temperature are set the same. Fig. 6 shows the energy consumption results of the respective conditioned zone over the simulation time. From the results, it can be found that the first-principles model-based PI control method consumes more cooling energy than that of the proposed hybrid model-based PI control method. The energy efficiency comparison in the four zones has been shown in Fig. 7. The average energy saving by the proposed hybrid model-based MFAC scheme can reach up to 25.5% compared with the first-principles model-based PI control. The additional cooling energy needs to be provided to depress the thermal effect of unmodeled factors. 4.3.3 Influence of hygro-thermal interaction on control performance This case is conducted to investigate zone thermal control performance with the consideration of influence of hygro-thermal interaction. The proposed MFAC scheme considered both thermal and wet interaction is employed for the zone-1. The previous results only considering the influence of thermal convection interaction in [16] are as the comparisons, which adopted MPC scheme to make prediction and control decision. Fig. 8(a) depicts the temperature variation when the AHU is turned on, which is controlled by MPC and MFAC, respectively. On the one hand, the results show that multi-zone model takes shorter time to drop the room temperature to the upper comfortable limit (23.5 °C) compared with single-zone model, and can afford zone comfort faster at the start of the occupancy. On the other hand, the hybrid model controlled by MFAC performs closer to the actual one than ANN-based multi-zone model controlled by MPC. Fig. 8(b) shows the temperature rising dynamics estimated by the prediction model in [16] and proposed hybrid model after the AHU is turned off. The results of proposed hybrid model can still predict better and closer to the actual situation than the ANN multi-zone model. From the above analysis, it can be concluded that the prediction model considering hygro-thermal interaction can perform better in multi-zone building climate control and energy saving in practice. 5 Conclusion With the consideration of unknown nonlinearity and uncertainty in the multi-zone HVAC system, we propose a hybrid modeling-based MFAC scheme to ensure both temperature and humidity setpoints tracking in spite of unknown disturbances. First, control-oriented hybrid model which integrates the first-principles model and FFDL-based data-driven model is developed for comprehensive multi-zone climate dynamics. Compared with the first-principles model existing unmodeled dynamics, the proposed hybrid model has considered unknown nonlinearity and uncertainty of the multi-zone hygro-thermal dynamics into the data model with the aid of online measured data. Then the MFAC scheme is designed including controller design, parameter estimation and reset mechanism to realize desired multi-zone climate control performance. The model validation shows that the proposed hybrid models have higher prediction accuracy compared with the first-principles models. PI as the baseline controller displays better set points tracking and less energy consumption based on the proposed hybrid models. Compared with PI control, it is an effective controller for multi-zone climate control that the proposed MFAC has improved system performance in faster convergence, without steady-state deviation. By considering influence of the hygro-thermal interaction, the proposed hybrid model controlled by MFAC shows potential to perform closer to the actual situation in multi-zone occupancy comfort. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, we study multi-zone air environment comfort and building energy conversation for the heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) system. Each zone is equipped with the air-handling unit (AHU) and fan coil unit to regulate the supply air state for comfortable zone climate. It is known that the multi-zone air environment appears spatial and temporal variation due to the hygro-thermal interaction which is an extremely complex nonlinear dynamic process. In this study, hybrid models incorporating the first-principles model with full form dynamic linearization (FFDL)-based data-driven model have been proposed to precisely describe the multi-zone climate dynamics including unknown nonlinearity and uncertainty. Then model-free adaptive control (MFAC) scheme is designed for multi-zone climate control, which contains controller design, parameter estimation and reset mechanism to ensure system control performance. Finally, different case studies are conducted to test the performance of model prediction and system control for the multi-zone climate environment. Model validation shows that the zone climate prediction of the proposed hybrid model shows better agreement with actual measured data. The step response results display that the hybrid model-based MFAC can realize multi-zone climate control performance improvement in faster convergence without stable bias. By comparing with prior work, the hybrid model-based MFAC has the potential to get closer to actual situation in cost-effective multi-zone climate control.
coredata.dc:title: Hybrid modeling-based temperature and humidity adaptive control for a multi-zone HVAC system
